abstract.p: The original Inventory of Depression and Anxiety Symptoms (IDAS) contains 11 nonoverlapping scales assessing specific depression and anxiety symptoms. In creating the expanded version of the IDAS (the IDAS-II), our goal was to create new scales assessing other important aspects of the anxiety disorders as well as key symptoms of bipolar disorder. Factor analyses of the IDAS-II item pool led to the creation of seven new scales (Traumatic Avoidance, Checking, Ordering, Cleaning, Claustrophobia, Mania, Euphoria) plus an expanded version of Social Anxiety. These scales are internally consistent and show strong convergent and significant discriminant validity in relation to other self-report and interview-based measures of anxiety, depression, and mania. Furthermore, the scales demonstrate substantial criterion and incremental validity in relation to interview-based measures of DSM-IV (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, fourth edition) symptoms and disorders. Thus, the expanded IDAS-II now assesses a broad range of depression, anxiety, and bipolar symptoms.

body.p: Watson et al. (2007) created the Inventory of Depression and Anxiety Symptoms (IDAS) to complement traditional self-report measures of depression, such as the Beck Depression Inventory–II (BDI-II; A. Beck, Steer, & Brown, 1996) and the Center for Epidemiological Studies–Depression Scale (CES-D; Radloff, 1977). The IDAS differs from these older instruments in two basic ways. First, unlike measures such as the BDI-II, the IDAS was specifically designed to include multiple scales assessing specific symptoms of depression (e.g., insomnia, appetite loss, suicidality). Second, a wide range of evidence has established that depression measures are strongly associated with symptoms of anxiety (e.g., Clark & Watson, 1991; Mineka, Watson, & Clark, 1998; Watson, 2005). Consequently, the original IDAS item pool contained a broad range of anxiety-related symptoms. The inclusion of these items facilitated the development of depression scales with good discriminant validity and also led to the creation of complementary anxiety scales.

The IDAS contains 11 nonoverlapping, factor analytically derived scales (see Watson et al., 2007). The Dysphoria scale—which contains items assessing depressed mood, anhedonia, worry, worthlessness, guilt, hopelessness, psychomotor disturbance, and cognitive difficulties—was created to capture the nature and scope of a large, nonspecific factor representing the core affective and cognitive symptoms of depression and anxiety (see Watson et al., 2007, table 1). It is not only a strong marker of general distress/negative affect but also contains a secondary component of low positive mood and, consequently, assesses the same basic dimension as the Demoralization scale of the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory–2–Restructured Form (MMPI-2-RF; Ben-Porath & Tellegen, 2008).

body.p: The 10 remaining scales assess specific symptom dimensions. Five scales represent specific symptoms of major depression: Insomnia, Lassitude (i.e., fatigue, lack of energy, and hypersomnia), Suicidality, Appetite Loss, and Appetite Gain. In addition, Ill Temper assesses feelings of anger and hostility that can serve as an alternative expression of depressed mood in children and adolescents (American Psychiatric Association, 2000), whereas Well-Being taps content reflecting high energy and positive affect that has been shown to be specifically related to depression (see Mineka et al., 1998; Watson, 2009a; Watson & Naragon-Gainey, 2010). The final three scales—Panic, Social Anxiety, and Traumatic Intrusions—tap specific types of anxiety symptoms.1

Watson et al. (2007) and Watson et al. (2008) presented extensive psychometric data to establish the reliability and validity of the IDAS scales. Watson et al. (2007) showed that the scales (a) are internally consistent, (b) have strong short-term stability, and (c) display good convergent and discriminant validity in relation to other self-report and interview-based measures of depression and anxiety. Watson et al. (2008) extended this evidence by demonstrating strong convergent validity and good discriminant validity between self-report and interview-based versions of the scales. In addition, Watson et al. (2008) examined relations with six Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, fourth edition (DSM-IV; American Psychiatric Association, 2000) mood and anxiety disorder diagnoses: major depression, generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), panic disorder, social phobia, and obsessive–compulsive disorder (OCD). Analyses revealed strong associations between (a) major depression and the IDAS Dysphoria and Well-Being scales, (b) panic disorder and IDAS Panic, (c) posttraumatic stress disorder and IDAS Traumatic Intrusions, and (d) social phobia and IDAS Social Anxiety.

sec.title: The Current Research: New IDAS-II Anxiety and Bipolar Symptom Scales
Purpose of the IDAS-II
sec.p: These data established that the original IDAS measures a large number of distinctive symptom dimensions in a relatively efficient manner (a total of 64 items). These encouraging results further suggested that it would be desirable to expand the instrument in order to assess mood and anxiety symptoms more comprehensively. This led to the creation of the expanded version of the IDAS or IDAS-II. Our basic goal in developing the IDAS-II was to create new scales assessing other important aspects of the anxiety disorders (e.g., OCD, agoraphobia) as well as key symptoms of bipolar disorder.

sec.title: Relation to existing symptom measures
sec.p: Most IDAS-II scales contain content (e.g., depressed mood, social anxiety, OCD symptoms) that also is tapped in other self-report scales. Nevertheless, we believe there are important advantages to subsuming all this diverse content within a single, more comprehensive inventory. First, because these scales were developed jointly using factor analysis, we were able to consider discriminant validity evidence directly when selecting items for the final measures. This enabled us to maximize differentiation among the scales so that each symptom cluster is assessed as clearly and distinctly as possible. Along these lines, we subsequently present data demonstrating that some IDAS-II scales show superior discriminant validity in comparison with existing alternatives.

Second, analyses of symptom structure currently are complicated by the influence of format and method variance. That is, all other things being equal, variables assessed in exactly the same way (e.g., using a common response format and time frame) will be more strongly related than those based on somewhat different methods (Johnson, Rosen, & Djurdjevic, 2011; Reio, 2010). The IDAS-II bypasses this problem of method-related variance and simplifies structural analyses by assessing all of this diverse content within a single common method, format, and time frame. Put differently, the IDAS-II permits one to examine relations among a diverse array of symptom content without having to model the confounding effects of methodological factors, such as format and time frame.

Third, although the IDAS-II bipolar scales contain content broadly similar to that found in several existing self-report measures, they assess this content somewhat differently. That is, widely used measures such as the General Behavior Inventory (GBI; Depue et al., 1981; Depue, Krauss, Spoont, & Arbisi, 1989) and the Hypomanic Personality Scale (HPS; Eckblad & Chapman, 1986) assess stable, long-term individual differences in manic/hypomanic tendencies. The Hypomania Checklist–32 (HCL-32; Angst et al., 2005) takes a different approach, asking respondents to indicate how they felt during an elevated mood state. In contrast, the new IDAS-II scales assess current (i.e., past 2 weeks) symptoms of bipolar disorder. Thus, these IDAS scales should provide information that differs somewhat from that obtainable from currently available measures.

sec.title: Relation to omnibus psychopathology inventories
sec.p: Of course, several popular measures—such as the MMPI-2-RF (Ben-Porath & Tellegen, 2008), the Personality Assessment Inventory (PAI; Morey, 2007), and the Millon Clinical Multiaxial Inventory–III (MCMI-III; Millon, 2009)—already assess a broad range of psychopathology. The IDAS-II differs from these other instruments in three important ways. First, as already noted, the IDAS-II explicitly assesses current (past 2 weeks) symptoms; thus, it does not measure the longer term, more stable forms of psychopathology (e.g., manifestations of personality pathology) that are captured by these other inventories.

Second, content coverage in the IDAS-II is restricted to symptoms of mood and anxiety disorders. The IDAS-II therefore is more focused than these other instruments, which also contain strong markers of both externalizing (e.g., MMPI-2-RF RC4 [Restructured Clinical], MCMI-III Alcohol Dependence, PAI Antisocial Features) and thought dysfunction (e.g., MMPI-2-RF RC8, PAI Schizophrenia, MCMI-III Thought Disorder).

Third, the IDAS-II—which takes advantage of recent data explicating the symptom structure of various DSM-IV disorders—provides more detailed and extensive coverage within its more limited range. For instance, as part of its assessment of anxiety symptoms, the PAI includes single measures of OCD (Obsessive–Compulsive), PTSD (Traumatic Stress) and phobia (Phobias). In contrast, as we describe subsequently, the expanded IDAS-II now contains (a) three OCD symptom scales, (b) two PTSD scales, and separate measures of (c) social anxiety/social phobia and (d) claustrophobia. Overall, the IDAS-II provides the most detailed and differentiated coverage of current mood and anxiety symptoms that is currently available.

sec.title: Homogeneous item composites
sec.p: In developing the initial item pool for the IDAS-II, we included multiple markers for each of the targeted symptom dimensions. To ensure that sufficient markers were included for each potential dimension, we rationally organized the candidate items into homogeneous item composites (Hogan, 1983) or HICs (for more detail regarding the logic of this approach, see Watson et al., 2007). Specifically, we developed 12 initial symptom clusters tapping PTSD (two HICs), OCD (three HICs), social phobia (two HICs), specific phobia (three HICs), agoraphobia (one HIC), and mania (one HIC). We now briefly review the rationale for each of these target dimensions.

sec.title: Posttraumatic stress disorder
sec.p: DSM-IV groups PTSD symptoms into three clusters: Criterion B (intrusions and reexperiencing of the trauma; five symptoms), Criterion C (emotional numbing and avoidance of trauma-related stimuli; seven symptoms); and Criterion D (manifestations of increased arousal; five symptoms). Structural studies, however, have provided extensive support for two different four-factor models (for a meta-analytic review, see Yufik & Simms, 2010). The first model, which initially was identified by King, Leskin, King, and Weathers (1998), follows the DSM-IV organization, except that the Criterion C symptoms are split into separate Avoidance (two symptoms) and Numbing (five symptoms) factors. The second model, which was proposed by Simms, Watson, and Doebbeling (2002), contains Intrusions and Avoidance factors that are identical to those specified in the King et al. scheme. However, it includes a smaller two-item Hyperarousal factor as well as a broad, nonspecific Dysphoria factor (eight symptoms) containing both Criterion C and Criterion D symptoms.

The IDAS already contains measures of intrusions and dysphoria. We expanded the coverage of PTSD symptoms in the IDAS-II item pool by including HICs related to avoidance and numbing. We chose not to create an additional HIC related to hyperarousal because this content already is well-captured in the instrument. That is, DSM-IV criteria D1 (difficulty falling or staying asleep), D2 (irritability or outbursts of anger), and D3 (difficulty concentrating) reflect content contained in the Insomnia, Ill Temper, and Dysphoria scales, respectively; the two remaining DSM-IV arousal symptoms (hypervigilance, exaggerated startle response) are captured by content in the Panic scale.

sec.title: Obsessive–compulsive disorder
sec.p: It now is recognized that OCD is heterogeneous and can be decomposed into several distinguishable symptom clusters (Leckman et al., 2010). Mataix-Cols, Rosario-Campos, and Leckman (2005) reviewed 12 major factor-analytic studies and established the existence of four highly replicable symptom dimensions: (a) symmetry and ordering, (b) cleaning and contamination, (c) obsessions and checking, and (d) hoarding. These same four symptom factors also have emerged consistently in item-level analyses of the Obsessive–Compulsive Inventory (OCI; Foa, Kozak, Salkovskis, Coles, & Amir, 1998), the OCI–Revised (OCI-R; Foa et al., 2002), and the Schedule of Compulsions, Obsessions, and Pathological Impulses (SCOPI; Watson & Wu, 2005; see Foa et al., 2002; Watson & Wu, 2005; Wu & Watson, 2003).

The original IDAS item pool contained a single 14-item HIC related to OCD symptoms; however, these items failed to define a replicable dimension in the main structural analyses (see Watson et al., 2007, Study 2). We suspected that our earlier approach was problematic in that we assessed OCD-related content in an undifferentiated manner, rather than targeting specific symptom dimensions (e.g., cleaning, ordering) systematically. We therefore expanded our coverage in the IDAS-II item pool to include three separate HICs related to cleaning, ordering/rituals, and checking/counting. We chose not to assess hoarding because although this symptom dimension is included in many OCD measures, it actually is linked to a broad range of psychopathology and is not clearly specific to OCD (Mataix-Cols et al., 2010; Watson & Wu, 2005; Wu & Watson, 2005).

sec.title: Social phobia
sec.p: The IDAS contains a single undifferentiated measure of social anxiety. However, there is replicated evidence for two distinguishable dimensions within social phobia: (a) a social interaction factor centered around fears related directly to interacting with others (e.g., initiating a conversation, making eye contact) and (b) a performance/scrutiny factor that focuses on fears of being watched by others, as well as engaging in activities (such as public speaking, writing, and eating) that would not be stressful if performed in private (Habke, Hewitt, Norton, & Asmundson, 1997; Hughes et al., 2006; LeBeau et al., 2010; Safren, Turk, & Heimberg, 1998). Moreover, these dimensions have shown distinctive correlates in several studies (e.g., Habke et al., 1997; Hughes et al., 2006; LeBeau et al., 2010). We therefore created two separate HICs tapping interaction and performance fears for inclusion in the IDAS-II item pool.

sec.title: Specific phobia and agoraphobia
sec.p: DSM-IV formally recognizes four subtypes of specific phobia: animal, natural environment (e.g., storms, heights, water), blood-injection-injury, and situational (e.g., tunnels, bridges, elevators, enclosed spaces). However, this quadripartite scheme was neither specifically derived from—nor was it supported by—any explicit structural evidence (see Craske et al., 1994). Factor analyses of multi-item phobia measures, such as the Fear Survey Schedule–III (FSS-III; Wolpe & Lang, 1974) and the Phobic Stimuli Response Scales (PSRS; Cutshall & Watson, 2004) provide consistent evidence for three of these subtypes: (a) animal fears, (b) blood-injection fears, and (c) some combination of situational and/or agoraphobic fears (Arrindell, Pickersgill, Merckelbach, Ardon, & Cornet, 1991; J. Beck, Carmin, & Henninger, 1998; Cutshall & Watson, 2004; Muris, Schmidt, & Merckelbach, 1999; Watson, 2009b). We included separate HICs representing these three replicated symptom dimensions (i.e., animal, blood-injection, and situational fears) in the IDAS-II item pool.

The original IDAS item pool contained a HIC assessing symptoms of agoraphobia; however, these items failed to define a replicable dimension in the initial round of structural analyses (see Watson et al., 2007, Study 1). We revisited this issue using a modified set of agoraphobia items in the IDAS-II pool.

sec.title: Bipolar symptoms
sec.p: The final HIC contained 20 items reflecting a broad array of symptoms related to manic and hypomanic episodes. The items in this cluster assessed grandiosity and an inflated sense of self-esteem (e.g., “I felt extremely important”), decreased need for sleep (e.g., “I did not feel any need for sleep”), talkativeness/pressure of speech (e.g., “My thoughts came so quickly I had trouble expressing them”), flight of ideas (e.g., “My thoughts jumped rapidly from one idea to another”), restlessness/agitation (e.g., “I had so much energy it was hard for me to sit still”), negative sequelae of excessive goal-directed activity (e.g., “I bought things I couldn’t afford”), affective lability (e.g., “I suddenly went from being elated to feeling irritated”), and elevated/euphoric mood (e.g., “I felt like I was ‘on top of the world’”).

sec.title: College student sample
sec.p: The participants were 307 undergraduate students enrolled in an introductory psychology course at the University of Iowa (Student Sample 1). They completed a battery of self-report questionnaires in partial fulfillment of a course research exposure requirement. The sample (M age = 19.3 years) consisted of 194 women and 113 men and was predominantly White (89.3%).

sec.title: Community adult sample
sec.p: The participants were 355 community-dwelling adults (Adult Sample 1) living in Eastern Iowa (age range = 25-80 years, M = 39.6 years). The sample consisted of 268 women and 86 men (the gender of one respondent was not specified); 308 participants (86.8%) were White. The participants were paid $15 for completing the survey.

sec.title: IDAS-II Item Pool
sec.p: The participants completed a 169-item version of the IDAS, along with other self-report measures (which will be described in Phase II); respondents indicated the extent to which they experienced each symptom “during the past two weeks, including today” on a 5-point scale ranging from not at all to extremely. The instrument included the final, 64-item version of the original IDAS, plus a 6-item measure of anxious mood (Watson et al., 2007).

The remaining 99 items were organized into 12 HICs; a research team that included several of the authors (DW, MWO, KNG, EK, MC, SMS) generated these new items, based on descriptions of the target constructs. As discussed previously, these HICs targeted the following dimensions: traumatic avoidance (7 items; e.g., avoided situations that brought up bad memories), numbing (7 items; e.g., felt cutoff from others), cleaning (9 items; e.g., worried a lot about germs), checking/counting (8 items; e.g., checked things repeatedly), ordering/rituals (7 items; e.g., needed to do things in a fixed, specific order), social interaction anxiety (6 items; e.g., felt nervous making small talk), performance/evaluation anxiety (6 items; e.g., felt uncomfortable eating or drinking in front of others), animal phobia (11 items; e.g., avoided bugs and insects), blood-injection phobia (4 items; e.g., felt faint at the sight of blood), situational phobia (8 items; e.g., was afraid of flying), agoraphobia (6 items; e.g., had trouble leaving my home), and bipolar symptoms (20 items; e.g., thoughts jumped rapidly from one idea to another).

sec.title: Basic Analytic Approach
sec.p: We conducted a separate series of principal factor analyses (using squared multiple correlations as the initial communality estimates) in each sample. All factors were rotated using both varimax (which constrains them to be orthogonal) and promax (which allows them to be correlated). In selecting dimensions as targets for scale development, we were guided by two basic principles. First, our goal was to identify the maximum number of factors (and scales) that were psychologically meaningful in order to differentiate specific types of symptoms as precisely as possible. Second, we only were interested in dimensions that were robust and generalizable; consequently, our final scales reflect factors that emerged clearly in both data sets. Specifically, to be retained for scale development, a dimension had to have at least three consistent markers across both samples; a marker was defined as a variable that (a) loaded at least |.35| on the target factor and (b) had loadings below |.30| on all other factors.

sec.title: Preliminary analyses
sec.p: Preliminary analyses of the candidate items revealed two problems related to poor construct differentiation/discriminant validity. First, the numbing items were very strongly related to the existing Dysphoria scale and failed to define a distinct dimension in our structural analyses. For example, a scale created by summing the seven candidate numbing items correlated .84 and .83 with Dysphoria in the student and community samples, respectively. This dimension therefore was dropped from further consideration.

Second, the social interaction and performance anxiety items were strongly correlated with both (a) each other and (b) the existing IDAS Social Anxiety scale. For instance, the summed social interaction candidate items correlated .79 and .84 with the performance items in the student and adult samples, respectively. Similarly, these summed scores had correlations with the existing Social Anxiety scale that ranged from .75 to .80 across the two samples. Not surprisingly, therefore, these items all loaded .50 or greater on a single common dimension that accounted for 93.7% and 89.9% of the common variance in the student and adult samples, respectively. We therefore abandoned the idea of creating separate social interaction and performance scales.

Additional analyses, however, indicated that we could enhance the psychometric properties of the existing Social Anxiety scale by adding in one of the performance items (“I was anxious about talking in public”); specifically, including this item increased the coefficient alpha for Social Anxiety without raising its correlations with other IDAS-II scales. We therefore added this item, thereby creating an expanded, six-item version of Social Anxiety in the IDAS-II.

sec.title: Creation of the IDAS-II anxiety scales
sec.p: Next, we conducted item-level principal factor analyses of the 80 remaining candidate symptoms; these analyses revealed eight clear, replicable content dimensions. Six of these factors tapped anxiety symptoms. Five factors closely resembled our rational HICs: Cleaning, Ordering, Checking, Traumatic Avoidance, and Animal Phobia. The sixth factor included items from both the agoraphobia and situational phobia HICs. This dimension makes good sense clinically; indeed, both the DSM-IV (Craske et al., 1994) and DSM-5 (LeBeau et al., 2010; Wittchen, Gloster, Beesdo-Baum, Fava, & Craske, 2010) anxiety disorders work groups have acknowledged the close connection between agoraphobia and the situational subtype of specific phobia. We labeled this hybrid dimension “Claustrophobia” to (a) reflect the core content of its strongest markers (e.g., “I felt anxious in small spaces”) and (b) emphasize its significant links to both agoraphobia and situational phobia (for a discussion of how claustrophobia relates to these disorders, see Craske et al., 1994). Finally, the blood-injection items failed to define a replicable factor in these samples; consequently, they were not considered further.

We created scales to assess these six robust dimensions. In selecting items for the final scales, we were guided by two basic considerations. First, we retained items that were the purest factor markers (i.e., had high loadings on that dimension and very low loadings on all other factors) and, therefore, maximized the discriminant validity of the scale vis-à-vis the others. Second, we minimized redundancy as much as possible and retained maximally distinct and informative items. On the basis of these considerations, we created a seven-item measure of Cleaning; five-item Ordering and Claustrophobia scales, a four-item measure of Traumatic Avoidance, and a three-item Checking scale. The final five-item Claustrophobia scale included three items from the original situational phobia HIC and two items from the agoraphobia HIC; the other scales drew all of their items from the corresponding HIC.

We also created a provisional nine-item Animal Phobia scale. Although this scale showed good internal consistency (coefficient α = .85 and .86 in the student and adult samples, respectively), it performed poorly in preliminary analyses of convergent and discriminant validity (based on measures described in Phase II). It therefore was dropped from further consideration, leaving us with five new anxiety scales.

sec.title: Creation of the IDAS-II bipolar scales
sec.p: The bipolar items defined two replicable factors. The first dimension had 11 consistent markers; these robust markers reflected talkativeness/pressure of speech, flight of ideas, affective lability, and the negative sequelae of excessive goal-directed activity; we labeled this dimension Mania. The second factor had seven consistent markers representing elevated mood, heightened energy, and grandiosity/excessive self-esteem; we labeled this dimension Euphoria.

We subsequently conducted correlational and factor analyses examining these 18 remaining items in relation to the original IDAS scales. Two types of Mania items—namely, those reflecting (a) affective lability and (b) the negative sequelae of excessive goal-related activity—showed poor discriminant validity in relation to Dysphoria; we dropped these items, creating a reduced five-item Mania scale. Similar analyses revealed that two Euphoria markers showed poor discriminant validity vis-à-vis the IDAS Well-Being scale. They therefore were dropped, creating the final five-item version of Euphoria.

Thus, the expanded IDAS-II now contains 99 items that are organized into 18 nonoverlapping scales, plus General Depression (which contains items from several other scales). In Phase II, we present data to establish the construct validity of these new scales.

sec.title: College student samples
sec.p: We collected validation data from six additional student samples. Student Samples 2 (N = 363), 3 (N = 219), 4 (N = 546), and 7 (N = 373) consisted of introductory psychology students at the University of Iowa (overall, these samples included 495 men, 961 women, 45 unspecified; M age = 19.0 years). Participants in Student Samples 5 (N = 727; 239 men, 488 women; M age = 21.1 years) and 6 (N = 342; 147 men, 195 women; M age = 19.6 years) were undergraduates at the University of North Texas and the University of Notre Dame, respectively. All students participated in partial fulfillment of a course research exposure requirement. With the exception of Student Sample 5, these participants were predominantly White (i.e., > 80%) and non-Hispanic. Student Sample 5 was 68.4% White, 15.3% African American, 5.7% Asian, and 10.6% other or nonspecified; 12.9% of these participants identified themselves as Hispanic or Latino.

With the exception of Student Sample 7, the students rated themselves on the complete, 99-item version of the IDAS-II. Responses from these groups will be collapsed into a combined student sample (overall N = 2,504) in several subsequent analyses. In contrast, the participants in Student Sample 7 completed only the Traumatic Intrusions, Traumatic Avoidance, Checking, Ordering, and Cleaning scales; their data will be included in analyses of convergent and discriminant validity.

sec.title: Community samples
sec.p: We collected validation data from two additional adult samples. Adult Sample 2 included 372 individuals living in Eastern Iowa (97 men, 274 women, 1 unspecified; M age = 36.7 years). Adult Sample 3 consisted of 364 individuals (147 men, 217 women; M age = 24.5 years) living in the greater South Bend metropolitan area. Respondents in both samples were compensated ($15 in Sample 2, $20 in Sample 3) for their participation.

Participants in both samples rated themselves on the complete, 99-item version of the IDAS-II. Responses from all of the community participants will be collapsed into a combined adult sample (overall N = 1,091) in several subsequent analyses.

sec.title: Patient samples
sec.p: We collected validation data from five samples of outpatients who currently were receiving mental health treatment. Patient Samples 1 (N = 94), 2 (N = 200), and 4 (N = 252) were outpatients living in Eastern Iowa (overall, these samples included 145 men, 398 women, 3 unspecified; M age = 37.8 years). Participants in these samples were predominantly White (i.e., ≥89% in each group) and non-Hispanic. All respondents were compensated ($15 in Sample 1, $40 in Sample 2, $30 in Sample 4) for their participation.

Participants in Patient Sample 3 (N = 394; 166 men, 224 women, 4 unspecified; M age = 42.3 years) were recruited from outpatient Psychology and Psychiatry clinics at Stony Brook University and from other local area facilities. Patients were paid $125 for their participation in a larger 5-hour study. This sample also was predominately White (81%) and non-Hispanic.

Patient Sample 5 (N = 220; 93 men, 126 women, 1 unspecified; M age = 43.1 years) consisted of outpatients living in the greater South Bend metropolitan area. Patients were compensated $40 for their participation. This sample was 63.6% White, 28.6% African American, and 7.8% multiracial or other.

With the exception of Patient Sample 4, the participants rated themselves on the complete, 99-item version of the IDAS-II. Responses from these groups will be collapsed into a combined patient sample (overall N = 908) in several subsequent analyses. The participants in Patient Sample 4 completed the same subset of IDAS-II scales as those in Student Sample 7 and will be included in the same series of validity analyses.

sec.title: IDAS-II
sec.p: Except as noted earlier, all participants were assessed using the complete 99-item version of the IDAS-II; respondents indicated the extent to which they experienced each symptom “during the past two weeks, including today” on a 5-point scale ranging from not at all to extremely.

sec.title: SCOPI
sec.p: Participants in the Student 3, Student 7, Patient 2, and Patient 4 samples completed the SCOPI (Watson & Wu, 2005), a factor analytically derived, multidimensional measure of OCD symptoms. We report data on three SCOPI scales: Obsessive Checking (14 items), Obsessive Cleanliness (12 items), and Compulsive Rituals (8 items). Participants rated their responses to each item on a 5-point scale ranging from strongly disagree to strongly agree. The SCOPI scales show strong convergence with scales on the OCI-R and other measures of OCD symptoms (Watson & Wu, 2005). Coefficient alphas in these samples were all .80 or greater.

sec.title: PTSD Checklist–Civilian Version (PCL)
sec.p: Participants in the Student 3, Student 7, Patient 2, and Patient 4 samples completed the PCL (Weathers, Litz, Herman, Huska, & Keane, 1993), which has 17 items corresponding to the DSM-IV symptom criteria for PTSD. Participants rate each symptom on a 5-point intensity scale based on their occurrence over the past month. Based on the four-factor models of King et al. (1998) and Simms et al. (2002), we will present convergent and discriminant validity data on scales assessing Intrusions (five items) and Avoidance (two items). Coefficient alphas were all .78 or greater.

sec.title: Fear Questionnaire (FQ)
sec.p: The FQ (Marks & Mathews, 1979) asks respondents to indicate the extent to which they would avoid various situations. Each item is rated on a 9-point scale ranging from would not avoid it to always avoid it. Participants in Student Sample 6 and Adult Sample 3 completed the Agoraphobia (five items) and Social Phobia (five items) scales. Coefficient alphas ranged from .69 to .81 across samples.

sec.title: Albany Panic and Phobia Questionnaire (APPQ)
sec.p: The APPQ (Rapee, Craske, & Barlow, 1994/1995) assesses symptoms of agoraphobia and social phobia, as well as fear of activities that produce interoceptive sensations. Respondents use a 9-point rating scale to describe how much fear they would experience if they were to encounter an activity or situation in the upcoming week. Participants in Student Sample 6 and Adult Sample 3 completed the Agoraphobia (9 items) and Social Phobia (10 items) scales. Coefficient alphas ranged from .77 to .90 across samples.

sec.title: Phobic Stimuli Response Scale
sec.p: Participants in the Student 1, Student 2, and Adult 1 samples completed the PSRS (Cutshall & Watson, 2004). The PSRS assesses content related to social phobia, agoraphobia, and specific phobia; items are rated on a 4-point scale ranging from strongly disagree to strongly agree. The PSRS contains five scales. One scale (Social; 11 items) assesses the interpersonal/evaluative fears characteristic of social phobia. Three other scales—Animal (8 items), Blood-Injection (10 items), and Bodily Harm (8 items)—measure various aspects of specific phobia. The final scale—Physical Confinement (9 items)—taps content related to both agoraphobia and situational phobia (e.g., “I dislike crowded places” and “I would be terrified if locked in a small, dark room”); it therefore should converge well with the IDAS-II Claustrophobia scale. Coefficient alphas for these scales ranged from .77 to .89 across the various samples.

sec.title: General Behavior Inventory
sec.p: Participants in the Student 1, Student 2, Student 6, Adult 1, and Adult 3 samples completed the GBI Hypomania and Biphasic scales (Depue et al., 1981; Depue, Krauss, et al., 1989). The GBI was designed to assess an individual’s likelihood of risk for bipolar disorder (see Depue et al., 1981). The 21-item Hypomania scale taps a broad range of bipolar symptoms (e.g., distractibility, reduced need for sleep, pressure of speech), whereas the 7-item Biphasic scale focuses more narrowly on affective lability (e.g., rapid shifts in mood or energy) and behavioral volatility (e.g., changes in eating patterns). Respondents rate how often they experience each item on a 4-point scale ranging from never or hardly to very often or almost constantly. Coefficient alphas ranged from .83 to .92.

sec.title: Hypomanic Personality Scale
sec.p: Participants in the Student 5, Student 6, and Adult 3 samples were assessed on the 48-item HPS (Eckblad & Chapman, 1986). Similar to the GBI, the HPS measures long-term manic/hypomanic tendencies, rather than current symptoms. The items are rated using a true–false format. In addition to creating a total score, we also examined the three HPS subscales recently developed by Schalet, Durbin, and Revelle (2011): Mood Volatility (12 items; e.g., “When I feel an emotion, I usually feel it with extreme intensity”), Social Vitality (19 items; e.g., “In unfamiliar surroundings, I am often so assertive and sociable that I surprise myself”), and Excitement (7 items; e.g., “I often feel excited and happy for no apparent reason”). This last scale—which assesses feelings of elation, excitement, energy, and high spirits—should converge particularly well with the IDAS-II Euphoria scale. Coefficient alphas for these scales ranged from .73 to .89 across samples.

sec.title: Hypomania Checklist–32
sec.p: Participants in Student Sample 6 and Adult Sample 3 completed the HCL-32 (Angst et al., 2005), which consists of 32 items that are rated using a dichotomous yes/no format. Respondents are asked to indicate how they felt during “a period when you were in a ‘high’ state.” Sample items include “I am more self-confident,” “I am less shy or inhibited,” and “I think faster.” Coefficient alphas for this scale were .79 (Student Sample 6) and .83 (Adult Sample 3).

sec.title: Clinician Rating Version of the IDAS (IDAS-CR)
sec.p: To examine the convergent and discriminant validity of the IDAS-II Traumatic Intrusions and Traumatic Avoidance scales, we obtained parallel clinical ratings using an expanded version of the IDAS-CR (Watson et al., 2008) in the Student 3, Student 7, Patient 2, and Patient 4 samples. Trained staff members conducted the interviews and rated the participants on each symptom dimension using a 3-point scale (absent, subthreshold, present). To make these ratings, the interviewers asked a standard initial probe question, as well as several standard follow-up questions, for each symptom. The interviewers also were free to ask additional questions to ensure that they had enough information to rate the individual confidently on the dimension (for further details regarding the IDAS-CR, see Koffel, 2011; Watson et al., 2008).

To assess interrater reliability, the interviews were audiotaped; a second interviewer independently scored 51 (Student Sample 3), 72 (Student Sample 7), 50 (Patient Sample 2), and 51 (Patient Sample 4) of these tapes. Intraclass correlations (ICCs) for Traumatic Intrusions ranged from .81 (Student Sample 3) to 1.00 (Patient Sample 4), with a median value of .92; corresponding values for Traumatic Avoidance ranged from .88 (Patient Sample 2) to .98 (Student Sample 7), with a median value of .95. ICCs in this range indicate excellent interrater reliability (Cicchetti, 1994).

sec.title: Personality, Cognitions, Consciousness, and Perceptions Interview (PCCP)
sec.p: To examine the convergent and discriminant validity of the IDAS-II Checking, Ordering, and Cleaning scales, we obtained parallel clinical ratings using the PCCP (Chmielewski & Watson, 2008b; Koffel, 2011) in the Student 3, Student 7, Patient 2, and Patient 4 samples. The PCCP is modeled after the IDAS-CR and uses the same 3-point rating scale (absent, subthreshold, present). To assess each symptom, the interviewer asks a standard probe question and three to five follow-up questions.

ICCs for Ordering (range = .81 to .92; median = .88) consistently indicated excellent interrater reliability. ICCs for Cleaning were in the excellent range in the Patient 2 (.83), Student 7 (.96), and Patient 4 (.98) samples, but the value in Student Sample 3 was somewhat lower (ICC = .68, which indicates “good” reliability). Finally, the interrater reliability for Checking was excellent in the Student 7 (ICC = .91) and Patient 4 (ICC = .96) samples, good in Patient Sample 2 (ICC = .71), and only fair in Student Sample 3 (ICC = .57).

sec.title: The Interview for Mood and Anxiety Symptoms (IMAS)
sec.p: We obtained symptom-level clinical ratings in Patient Sample 3 using the IMAS. The IMAS (Gamez, Kotov, & Watson, 2010; Watson et al., 2007) assesses current (i.e., past month) symptoms without the use of skip-outs; that is, every question is asked of every participant. Items were derived from the mood and anxiety disorder modules of the Composite International Diagnostic Interview (CIDI; Kessler & Üstün, 2004) and were designed to cover all DSM-IV mood and anxiety disorder symptom criteria. Based on data from prior studies (Gamez et al., 2010; Watson et al., 2007), the IMAS was revised to improve its symptom coverage. The revised version—which consists of 10 scales corresponding to major DSM-IV anxiety and mood syndromes, plus irritability—was used in this study: Depression (49 items; α = .95), GAD (12 items; α = .89), PTSD (25 items; α = .89), Panic (23 items; α = .87), Agoraphobia (15 items; α = .87), Social Phobia (15 items; α = .88), Specific Phobia (13 items; α = .81), OCD (19 items; α = .92), Mania (20 items; α = .88), and Irritability (6 items; α = .87).

Extensively trained lay interviewers administered the IMAS. Individual items are scored on a 3-point rating scale (absent, subthreshold, above threshold). All interviews were recorded; a randomly selected interviewer rescored 34 tapes. Interrater reliability consistently was excellent, with ICCs ranging from .97 to .99 across the various scales.

sec.title: Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV (SCID-IV)
sec.p: To obtain current DSM-IV diagnoses, participants in Patient Sample 3 (N = 290) were interviewed using the mood disorders and anxiety disorders modules of the SCID-IV (First, Spitzer, Gibbon, & Williams, 1997). The interviewers were graduate students in clinical psychology who had completed their master’s degree and received formal training in the SCID. We report results on nine current mood and anxiety disorder diagnoses in this sample: major depression (prevalence rate = 26.2%), manic episode (7.6%), GAD (27.6%), PTSD (16.6%), panic disorder (26.9%), agoraphobia (22.4%), social phobia (25.5%), specific phobia (32.8%), and OCD (12.8%).

sec.title: Analytic Overview
sec.p: To explicate the construct validity of the IDAS-II scales, we present three basic types of analyses. First, we describe general properties of the scales (e.g., internal consistency, descriptive statistics) and examine the internal structure of the expanded instrument. Next, we analyze the convergent and discriminant validity of the new IDAS-II scales in relation to self-report and interview-based measures of the same constructs. Finally, we examine the criterion validity of the scales by relating them to current DSM-IV disorders.

sec.title: Internal Consistency
sec.p: Table 1 presents internal consistency data (coefficient alphas) and average interitem correlations (AICs) for the IDAS-II scales in the overall patient, adult, and student samples; it also provides median values to facilitate cross-sample comparisons. The alpha values generally were strong, with the large majority falling in the range of .80 to .90. The values for Euphoria were a bit lower, however, ranging from .72 (Adults) to .79 (Patients).

Ideally, the AIC for a scale should be moderate, falling between .15 and .50 (Clark & Watson, 1995); given that these symptom scales are specific in scope, one would expect their values to be in the upper part of this range. Five of the new or revised scales—Cleaning, Social Anxiety, Ordering, Mania, and Euphoria—met this general expectation, with AICs ranging from .34 to .56 across samples. Overall, these scales tap a range of moderately related content. The results for the five-item Claustrophobia scale were more variable: its AIC was moderate (.53) in the students but higher in the adults (.59) and patients (.62). In contrast, the AICs for Traumatic Avoidance and Checking were consistently higher (≥.65); these two scales clearly subsume a narrow range of content.

sec.title: Descriptive Statistics
sec.p: Table 2 presents scale means and standard deviations in the combined patient, adult, and student samples. As would be expected, the patients reported the highest levels of psychopathology; the students generally obtained intermediate scores, with the adults showing the healthiest functioning. To quantify these group differences, we computed effect sizes using Cohen’s d (Cohen, 1992) by (a) calculating the difference between the mean scale scores of two groups and then (b) dividing this value by the pooled standard deviation. Cohen (1992, table 1) proposed that d values from |0.20| to |0.49| represent small effect sizes; those ranging from |0.50| to |0.79| reflect medium effect sizes; and values of |0.80| or greater indicate large effect sizes. Based on these cutoffs, the patients reported substantially greater levels of psychopathology (i.e., medium or large effect sizes) in 13 of 18 comparisons involving the adults and in 8 of the 18 comparisons with the students; in contrast, mean-level differences between the students and adults consistently were small in magnitude.

sec.p: The results for four of the new or revised scales (Traumatic Avoidance, Claustrophobia, Social Anxiety, and Mania) conformed to this general trend. In contrast, however, group differences on the three OCD scales consistently were small, with ds ranging from only 0.30 to 0.47 in the patient–adult comparisons, and from only 0.04 to 0.14 in the patient–student analyses. These small group differences, in part, could reflect the fact that subclinical manifestations of OCD symptoms are quite common in the general population (Fullana et al., 2009; Ruscio, Stein, Chiu, & Kessler, 2010). Moreover, these data are consistent with the more general observation that OCD symptoms contain a relatively modest component of general distress/demoralization—the nonspecific dimension that broadly differentiates clinical from nonclinical samples—in comparison with other indicators of depression and anxiety (Watson, 2009a). Nevertheless, these results do raise potential concerns regarding the construct validity of these new OCD scales that we address in subsequent analyses.

The results for the new Euphoria scale are even more striking: Patients had significantly lower scores than both adults (d = −0.10) and students (d = −0.34). These results raise potential concerns about the validity of this new scale. That is, one could argue that it simply assesses a particular type of positive mood rather than tapping a significant form of psychopathology. We address these concerns in subsequent analyses.

sec.title: Scale correlations
sec.p: For ease of presentation, to examine the correlations among the IDAS-II scales, we report combined data collapsed across all the samples (N = 4,503). To eliminate mean-level differences across populations (i.e., patients vs. adults vs. students), we standardized the scale scores on a within-population basis and then combined them to permit a single overall analysis. Table 3 presents the scale correlations in this overall standardized combined sample. Three aspects of these data are noteworthy. First, the new IDAS-II scales tend to be less related to Dysphoria than the original IDAS scales. Table 3 indicates that the other 10 original IDAS scales (including the expanded version of Social Anxiety) had correlations with Dysphoria that ranged from −.40 (Well-Being) to .69 (Lassitude), with a mean value of |.57|. In contrast, the seven new scales had correlations ranging from .08 (Euphoria) to .56 (Mania), with a mean value of only |.40|. These data indicate that the content of these new scales is less strongly saturated with the nonspecific variance that lies at the core of the distress disorders (see Watson, 2005, 2009a).

caption.p: Correlations Among the IDAS-II Scales (Standardized Combined Sample)

fn.p: Note. IDAS-II = Expanded version of the Inventory of Depression and Anxiety Symptoms N = 4,503. Correlations of .55 and higher are in boldface. Correlations > |.03| are significant at p < .05.

sec.p: Second, one would expect to see particularly strong correlations between (a) the two trauma scales and (b) the three OCD scales; Table 3 confirms this expectation. Nevertheless, the correlations between the two trauma scales (r = .63) and between Checking and Ordering (r = .63) are high enough to raise potential discriminant validity concerns that we address in subsequent analyses.

Third, Euphoria generally correlated weakly with the other scales, with two exceptions: it was substantially positively related to both Well-Being (r = .51) and Mania (r = .45). Indeed, a multiple regression analysis—with Mania and Well-Being as predictors and Euphoria as the criterion—yielded an R of .68, indicating that these scales jointly accounted for 46% of its variance. On the basis of these results, it seems reasonable to suggest that Euphoria taps a form of positive affect that is specifically related to mania.

These findings are unusual for two reasons. First, Well-Being and Mania are completely unrelated to one another (r = .02). Second, Euphoria has a substantial positive correlation with both scales, despite the fact that Mania and Well-Being tend to relate oppositely to other variables. This curious pattern is helpful in explaining its associations with other variables, which can be viewed as a compromise between two opposing forces (i.e., Well-Being and Mania). For example, Mania (r = .56) and Well-Being (r = −.40) are oppositely related to Dysphoria; Euphoria essentially splits the difference and, consequently, has a weak positive correlation with Dysphoria (r = .08). Similarly, Euphoria’s correlation with Ill Temper (r = .19) falls between those of Mania (r = .46) and Well-Being (r = −.21). Note that these results also provide a context for understanding the mean-level findings discussed earlier. For example, patients reported higher levels of Mania (d = 0.57)—but substantially lower levels of Well-Being (d = −0.66)—than adults. Euphoria again essentially splits the difference between these two effects, such that patients had slightly lower scores (d = −0.10) on this scale.

This unusual pattern might suggest that Euphoria represents a “shotgun wedding” of two unrelated components. This is not the case, however. In fact, the correlations among its five items ranged from .31 to .57 in this overall standardized sample, with a mean value of .40; moreover, its items all loaded .50 or higher on the first principal factor in these data. Thus, this duality of content is inherent in the items themselves.

sec.title: Factor structure of the IDAS-II
sec.p: Analyses of the original IDAS scales yielded a single general factor that (a) accounted for 85.9% to 95.4% of the common variance and (b) essentially was defined by the Dysphoria scale (which had loadings ranging from .89 to .93 across eight samples; see Watson et al., 2007, table 5). We examined how the inclusion of the seven new scales altered the internal structure of the expanded instrument by subjecting the data from the standardized combined sample (N = 4,503) to a principal factor analysis. These analyses revealed the presence of three interpretable factors, which were rotated to oblique simple structure using promax (see Table 4). Factor I—which we labeled “Distress”—closely resembled the general factor of the original instrument and again essentially was defined by Dysphoria (which had a loading of .90). Factor II (“Obsessions/Fear”) was marked primarily by the three OCD scales (loadings ranged from .64 to .72); Claustrophobia (.60) and Social Anxiety (.41) also had salient loadings on this dimension. Factor III (“Positive Mood”) was defined primarily by Euphoria (.70) and Well-Being (.69); Mania also had a significant secondary loading (.33) on this dimension. Thus, the inclusion of the new scales—which provided most of the markers for Factors II and III—has expanded the scope and complexity of the instrument by moving it beyond distress-based symptoms of internalizing.

sec.title: OCD symptoms
sec.p: We report convergent and discriminant validity data on three OCD symptom dimensions (checking, ordering, cleaning), each of which was assessed via three different measures: clinicians’ ratings (PCCP) and two different self-report inventories (IDAS-II, SCOPI). Correlations among these variables are presented in Table 5 in the form of a multitrait–multimethod matrix; the data are reported separately for patients (collapsed across the Patient 2 and Patient 4 samples; N = 448) and students (the combined Student 3 and Student 7 samples; N = 591).2

All correlations are significant at p < .05. IDAS-II = Expanded version of the Inventory of Depression and Anxiety Symptoms; SCOPI = Schedule of Compulsions, Obsessions, and Pathological Impulses; PCCP = Personality, Cognitions, Consciousness, and Perceptions Interview.

sec.p: We see strong evidence of convergent validity in these data. As one would expect, the level of convergence is particularly impressive between the two sets of self-report scales, which produced an overall mean r of .72 across all symptoms and samples. It also is noteworthy that the IDAS-II (mean convergent r = .59) and SCOPI (mean r = .59) scales showed similarly strong correlations with the clinical ratings. Finally, it is reassuring to see that the convergent correlations were substantial across all three symptom dimensions (for cleaning, mean r = .67; for ordering, mean r = .66; for checking, mean r = .59) and in both the patient (mean r = .67) and student (mean r = .61) data.

We turn now to discriminant validity. In discussing these data, it is important to emphasize that valid measures of OCD symptoms should not be completely independent of one another but rather should be significantly interrelated. Thus, the key issue here is the pattern of the correlations; that is, whether purported measures of the same construct (e.g., IDAS-II Checking vs. PCCP Checking) correlate more highly than purported measures of different constructs (e.g., IDAS-II Checking vs. PCCP Ordering).

A classic test of discriminant validity is that each of the convergent correlations should be higher than any of the other values in its row or column of the heteromethod block (Campbell & Fiske, 1959). All the scales easily met this criterion; indeed, all the convergent correlations were at least .14 greater than the discriminant coefficients in the same row or column of the heteromethod block. We tested these differences formally using the Williams modification of the Hotelling test for two correlations involving a common variable (Kenny, 1987), again comparing the convergent correlations with each of the discriminant coefficients in the same row or column of the heteromethod block. There are six different heteromethod blocks in Table 5, which yield a total of 72 individual comparisons. All 72 comparisons were significant (p < .01, one-tailed; zs ranged from 4.55 to 11.49). Thus, we see clear evidence of discriminant validity, even between strongly correlated measures of checking and ordering.

sec.title: PTSD symptoms
sec.p: We report convergent and discriminant validity data on two PTSD symptom dimensions (intrusions and avoidance), each of which was assessed by two different self-report scales (IDAS-II, PCL) as well as by clinicians’ ratings (IDAS-CR). Table 6 presents correlations among these variables in the form of a multitrait–multimethod matrix; as with the OCD analyses, these results are reported separately for patients (the combined Patient Samples 2 and 4; N = 448) and students (the combined Student Samples 3 and 7; N = 591).

sec.p: Paralleling the OCD data, we see strong evidence of convergent validity in these analyses. As would be expected, the convergence was particularly impressive between the IDAS-II and PCL scales, with an overall mean r of .73 across all analyses. Both sets of self-report scales also converged well with clinician ratings on the IDAS-CR, although the coefficients for the IDAS-II (mean r = .60) were slightly stronger overall than those for the PCL (mean r = .56). Finally, it is worth noting that the convergent correlations were substantial in both the patient (mean r = .67) and student (mean r = .61) data and across measures of both intrusions (mean r = .64) and avoidance (mean r = .64).

PTSD symptom dimensions contain a large component of general distress and tend to be strongly interrelated (Watson, 2009a; Yufik & Simms, 2010). Consistent with this broader trend, the discriminant correlations were relatively high, particularly within the self-report data (rs ranged from .60 to .80 across scales and samples); the discriminant correlations in the clinicians’ ratings were somewhat lower but still were substantial (r = .61 and .64 in patients and students, respectively). We conducted significance tests comparing each of the convergent correlations to the other values in its row or column of the heteromethod block. It is noteworthy that all 16 comparisons involving the IDAS-II Traumatic Intrusions and Traumatic Avoidance scales were statistically significant (p < .05, one-tailed; zs ranged from 1.72 to 7.07 in the patients and from 1.66 to 4.64 in the students). Thus, these IDAS-II scales show consistent evidence of discriminant validity in these data. In contrast, the discriminant validity of the PCL scales was more modest; overall, only 11 of the 16 comparisons involving these scales were significant (p < .05, one-tailed).

sec.title: Social anxiety and claustrophobia
sec.p: Next, we examine the convergent and discriminant validity of the IDAS-II Social Anxiety and Claustrophobia scales vis-à-vis conceptually related measures from the FQ, APPQ, and PSRS. For ease of presentation, we report combined data from all relevant samples (see Table 7). Given that these data were collected from both students and adults, we again standardized the scales on a within-population basis and then combined them to permit a single overall analysis.

sec.p: Table 7 indicates that IDAS-II Social Anxiety correlated strongly with the social phobia scales of the APPQ (r = .68), PSRS (r = .59), and FQ (r = .53), thereby establishing its convergent validity. Follow-up statistical tests indicated that all three social phobia scales correlated significantly more strongly with Social Anxiety than with any other IDAS-II scale (zs ranged from 6.33 to 15.63), which provides evidence of discriminant validity.

As expected, IDAS-II Claustrophobia was strongly related (r = .51) to the PSRS Physical Confinement scale. Follow-up tests indicated that Physical Confinement correlated significantly more strongly with Claustrophobia than with any other IDAS-II scale (zs ranged from 4.10 to 7.52). In contrast, Claustrophobia correlated more weakly with measures of agoraphobia (r = .30 and .37 with FQ Agoraphobia and APPQ Agoraphobia, respectively). These data are consistent with our earlier argument that the IDAS-II Claustrophobia scale assesses content related to both agoraphobia and situational phobia (as does PSRS Physical Confinement), rather than representing a specific indicator of either domain.

sec.title: Bipolar symptoms
sec.p: Finally, we explicate the convergent and discriminant validity of the IDAS-II bipolar symptom scales by relating them to existing self-report measures of mania. Table 8 presents correlations between the mania measures and the IDAS-II scales. It also displays multiple Rs from a series of regression analyses in which all 18 IDAS-II scales were used to predict each of the mania scores. The IDAS-II scales jointly accounted for 24% (HPS Social Vitality) to 50% (GBI Biphasic) of the variance in six of the seven criteria; clearly, however, their combined ability to predict the HCL-32 (R2 = .17) was substantially weaker. Overall, these results indicate that the IDAS-II scales jointly account for a substantial amount of the variance in commonly used self-report measures of mania.

sec.p: Looking now at specific scales, IDAS-II Mania was substantially related to several other measures, displaying particularly strong associations with GBI Hypomania (r = .56), HPS Mood Volatility (r = .54), and GBI Biphasic (r = .51). As expected, Euphoria correlated more strongly with HPS Excitement (r = .45) than with the other HPS subscales (r = .34 and .31 with Social Vitality and Mood Volatility, respectively); Euphoria also was moderately correlated with the HPS Total score (r = .45) and with GBI Hypomania (r = .44), which further demonstrates its convergent validity.

Next, we conducted significance tests to identify specific convergent/discriminant patterns in these data. These analyses revealed that (a) the HPS Total score and HCL-32 correlated more strongly with Euphoria and Mania than with any other IDAS-II scale (zs ranged from 2.23 to 17.37); (b) GBI Hypomania and HPS Mood Volatility correlated more strongly with Mania than with any other IDAS-II scale (zs ranged from 2.33 to 17.95); and (c) HPS Excitement and HPS Social Vitality correlated more strongly with Euphoria than with any other IDAS-II scale (zs ranged from 4.87 to 13.24). Thus, the Table 8 data display a clear convergent/discriminant pattern and help to establish the construct validity of the IDAS-II bipolar scales.

Finally, it is noteworthy that the GBI Biphasic scale correlated significantly more strongly with Dysphoria (r = .62) than with any other IDAS-II scale (zs ranged from 5.22 to 19.00). This finding is consistent with our Phase I structural analyses, which indicated that affective lability items showed poor discriminant validity vis-à-vis Dysphoria.

sec.title: IMAS analyses
sec.p: We now examine the criterion validity of the IDAS-II scales by relating them to current DSM-IV disorders. We first consider correlations with the IMAS scales—which are interview-based measures of DSM-IV symptoms—in Patient Sample 3 (see Table 9). It is noteworthy that (a) IDAS-II Social Anxiety had the strongest association with IMAS Social Phobia (r = .70); (b) all three OCD scales showed clear specificity to IMAS OCD (rs range from .66 to .68); (c) Claustrophobia had the strongest links to both Agoraphobia (r = .71) and Specific Phobia (r = .49); (d) Euphoria (r = .64) and Mania (r = .63) both were strongly and specifically related to IMAS Mania; (e) Ill Temper was substantially related to Irritability (r = .72); and (f) Dysphoria was the best predictor of both Depression (r = .74) and GAD (r = .72). There are a few anomalies, however. For example, IDAS-II Panic had the strongest association with IMAS Panic (r = .65) but it was equally related to GAD (r = .63). In addition, although Traumatic Intrusions (r = .61) and Traumatic Avoidance (r = .59) both were substantially correlated with PTSD, so was Dysphoria (r = .63). In general, however, the associations shown in Table 9 make good sense conceptually and support the criterion validity of the IDAS-II scales.

sec.p: In terms of the individual scales (a) Traumatic Intrusions and Traumatic Avoidance both contributed significantly to the prediction of PTSD; (b) Social Anxiety and Panic were the strongest predictors of Social Phobia and Panic, respectively; (c) Claustrophobia made the strongest contributions to both Agoraphobia and Specific Phobia; (d) Checking, Ordering, and Cleaning were the only significant predictors of OCD; (e) Euphoria and Mania had the strongest associations with IMAS Mania; (f) Ill Temper was the only significant predictor of Irritability; and (g) Dysphoria made the strongest contribution to both Depression and GAD. Finally, (h) Cleaning also was secondarily related to Specific Phobia. This last finding is consistent with previous research and likely reflects the shared role of contamination-related fears and disgust sensitivity in both types of symptoms (e.g., Cisler, Olatunji, & Lohr, 2009; Muris, van der Heiden, & Rassin, 2008); its emergence in these data highlights the potential benefits of assessing these OCD symptom dimensions separately.

sec.title: SCID-IV analyses
sec.p: Next, we examine relations with formal DSM-IV diagnoses in this same sample. We begin with associations at the bivariate level. In examining scale-diagnosis relations, a problem with standard Pearson product–moment correlations is that they are substantially influenced by the differential base rates of various disorders; specifically, they will be inflated for more common diagnoses and attenuated for less prevalent syndromes, regardless of the true strength of the relations (see Kotov, Gamez, Schmidt, & Watson, 2010; Watson et al., 2008). Accordingly, Table 11 presents polychoric correlations between the IDAS-II scales and nine DSM-IV mood and anxiety disorder diagnoses. Polychoric correlations estimate the associations between normally distributed latent continuous variables that are presumed to underlie observed scores (Flora & Curran, 2004; Schmukle & Egloff, 2009; Watson & Tellegen, 1999). They retain the relative rank order information provided by Pearson correlations (i.e., the same scales will be relatively strong—or weak—predictors of particular diagnoses) but are unaffected by differences in prevalence rates, thereby facilitating cross-diagnosis comparisons. Diagnoses were scored as 0 = absent, 1 = present, so that positive correlations indicate that higher scores on a scale are associated with an increased likelihood of receiving the diagnosis.

sec.p: These results closely parallel the IMAS analyses. Once again (a) Traumatic Intrusions (polychoric r = .51) and Traumatic Avoidance (r = .48) both were substantially related to PTSD; (b) Social Anxiety displayed the strongest association (r = 48) with social phobia; (c) Claustrophobia was linked to both agoraphobia (r = .54) and specific phobia (r = .48); (d) Ordering and Checking were specifically related to OCD (r = .55 and .45, respectively); (e) Cleaning was correlated with both OCD (r = .51) and specific phobia (r = .50); (f) Euphoria (r = .47) and Mania (r = .33) both were significantly associated with current manic episodes; and (g) Dysphoria had the strongest association with major depression (r = .67) and GAD (r = .35). One anomaly is that the IDAS-II Panic scale (r = .43) did not show a particularly strong or specific link to panic disorder. Generally speaking, however, these data are consistent with expectations and further establish the criterion validity of the IDAS-II scales.

Next, we conducted a series of logistic regression analyses (another unbiased approach to modeling associations between dichotomous and continuous variables) to identify the unique, incremental ability of the individual IDAS-II scales to predict each DSM-IV disorder. To facilitate interpretation, the symptom scales were standardized to put them on the same metric. Table 12 presents the odds ratios (ORs) from these analyses. It is noteworthy that (a) Traumatic Intrusions contributed significantly to the prediction of PTSD; (b) Panic had the strongest association with panic disorder; (c) Social Anxiety was the only significant predictor of social phobia; (d) Claustrophobia made a unique, incremental contribution to agoraphobia; (e) Ordering was a significant predictor of OCD; (f) Cleaning contributed significantly to both OCD and specific phobia; and (g) Dysphoria was significantly related to both depression and GAD. Three other effects approached significance: Traumatic Avoidance with PTSD (OR = 1.60, 95% confidence interval [CI] = 0.93-2.75, p = .087), Claustrophobia with specific phobia (OR = 1.43, 95% CI = 0.94-2.17, p = .091), and Euphoria with current manic episodes (OR = 2.01, 95% CI = 0.99-4.10, p = .054). Two expected findings, however, failed to emerge. (a) Checking did not predict OCD and (b) Mania failed to contribute to current manic episodes.
