sec.title: Basic Properties of the New Scales
sec.p: Our goal was to create specific symptom scales tapping important aspects of the mood and anxiety disorders not already assessed in the IDAS. We believe we were successful in achieving this goal. Our factor analyses revealed several distinct, interpretable, and replicable symptom dimensions. The resulting scales are internally consistent; moreover, with a few exceptions, the correlations among the scales are moderate in magnitude, suggesting that they reflect distinctive types of symptoms. Finally, these new IDAS-II scales showed good convergent, discriminant, and criterion validity when related to other self-report and interview-based measures of anxiety, depression, and mania.

sec.title: OCD scales
sec.p: We developed scales that captured our three target dimensions of checking, ordering/rituals, and cleaning. Despite the relatively strong correlation between Checking and Ordering (see Table 3), the scales showed significant convergent and discriminant validity in relation to both (a) self-ratings on the SCOPI and (b) clinician ratings on the PCCP (see Table 5). They also displayed clear specificity in the criterion validity analyses. For example, they had correlations ranging from .66 to .68 (mean r = .67) with the IMAS OCD scale; their correlations with the other IMAS scales ranged from .22 to .43, with a mean value of only .32. Similarly, their polychoric correlations with OCD diagnoses ranged from .45 to .55 (mean r = .50); in contrast, their correlations with other disorders (with the exception of the link between Cleaning and specific phobia) ranged from .05 to .34, with a mean coefficient of only .19. The only notable exception to this pattern involved Cleaning, which also correlated strongly with DSM-IV diagnoses of specific phobia (r = .50). Finally, the scales contributed significantly to the prediction of OCD in both the SCID and IMAS analyses.

Unlike Checking and Ordering, Cleaning also contributed significantly to the prediction of specific phobia in both the IMAS and SCID analyses. As noted earlier, this association likely reflects the shared role of contamination-related fears and disgust sensitivity in certain aspects of OCD (i.e., washing/cleaning) and specific phobia (especially the animal and blood-injection-injury subtypes; see Cisler et al., 2009). This distinctive pattern of associations highlights the potential advantages of assessing these OCD symptom dimensions separately.

sec.title: PTSD scales
sec.p: We included items related to both avoidance and numbing in the IDAS-II item pool. The numbing items were very strongly related to the existing Dysphoria scale, however, and failed to define a distinct dimension in our structural analyses; we therefore abandoned our attempt to create a separate measure of numbing in the IDAS-II.

We were successful in creating a measure of Traumatic Avoidance, however, so that the expanded IDAS-II now includes two trauma-based scales (the other being Traumatic Intrusions). These scales showed significant convergent and discriminant validity in relation to both (a) self-ratings on the PCL and (b) clinician ratings on the IDAS-CR (see Table 6). They also displayed clear specificity in the criterion validity analyses. Traumatic Intrusions had a mean correlation of .56 with our two PTSD criteria (see Tables 9 and 11); in contrast, its correlations with the other disorders ranged from .02 to .54, with an average value of only .31. Similarly, Traumatic Avoidance had an average correlation of .54 with the PTSD criteria; its other correlations ranged from .12 to .54, with a mean value of only .33. Finally, Traumatic Intrusions contributed significantly to the prediction of PTSD in both analyses; taken together with the results of Watson et al. (2008), it now has shown incremental validity in predicting PTSD in three separate analyses. Traumatic Avoidance also made an incremental contribution in both analyses, although this effect only approached significance in the SCID data.

sec.title: Social anxiety
sec.p: We attempted to create separate scales tapping social interaction and performance fears in the IDAS-II. This attempt failed, as all our social anxiety items defined a single undifferentiated dimension. However, we were able to create an expanded, six-item version of the Social Anxiety scale by adding in one of the newly written performance items. This augmented scale consistently showed good convergent, discriminant, and criterion validity in our data. It correlated strongly with self-report social phobia measures from the APPQ (r = .68), PSRS (r = .59), and FQ (r = .53). It also displayed clear specificity in the criterion validity analyses. Overall, Social Anxiety had a mean correlation of .59 with our social phobia criteria; in contrast, its correlations with the other disorders ranged from .05 to .59, with an average value of only .37. Finally, Social Anxiety contributed significantly to the prediction of social phobia in both analyses; taken together with the results of Watson et al. (2008), this scale now has shown incremental validity in predicting social phobia in three separate analyses.

sec.title: Claustrophobia
sec.p: We included four separate groups of items assessing animal phobia, blood-injection phobia, situational phobia, and agoraphobia in the IDAS-II pool. The blood-injection items failed to define a replicable factor in our scale development samples and were dropped from further consideration. A provisional Animal Phobia scale performed poorly in preliminary analyses of convergent and discriminant validity; it also was dropped. Finally, items from the agoraphobia and situational phobia HICs jointly defined a robust factor. We created the IDAS-II Claustrophobia scale—which contains three of the original situational phobia items plus two agoraphobia items—to assess this dimension.

Consistent with its origins, this scale is best viewed as assessing content related to both agoraphobia and situational phobia, rather than as a specific indicator of either domain. For example, it correlated more strongly with the PSRS Physical Confinement scale (r = .51) than with specific measures of agoraphobia (rs ranged from .30 to .37). Furthermore, it correlated substantially with interview-based measures of both agoraphobia (mean r = .62) and specific phobia (mean r = .48), and contributed to the prediction of both disorders in our criterion validity analyses (although the effect in the SCID data only approached significance). We believe that its inclusion represents an important expansion of the symptom coverage in the IDAS-II. In this regard, Watson et al. (2008) found that the original IDAS scales accounted for little variance in diagnoses of specific phobia; in contrast, our current data establish that the IDAS-II scales now account for substantial variance in both specific phobia and agoraphobia.

sec.title: Bipolar scales
sec.p: We created two bipolar symptom scales for the IDAS-II. The new Mania scale showed substantial convergent validity with existing self-report mania scales; it converged particularly well with GBI Hypomania (r = .56), HPS Mood Volatility (r = .54), and GBI Biphasic (r = .51). Moreover, Mania exhibited significant criterion validity across various analyses. It correlated particularly strongly (r = .63) with the IMAS Mania scale and also was significantly associated with current manic episode diagnoses (r = .33). Multivariate analyses indicated that the scale showed significant incremental power in predicting IMAS Mania (β = .35), but not in relation to current manic episodes on the SCID. Overall, the available evidence is encouraging, in that it indicates that the scale (a) overlaps substantially with existing self-report measures of mania and (b) captures clinically meaningful variance that is specifically related to DSM-IV bipolar disorders.

The new Euphoria scale has some curious properties. Most notably, it had substantial positive correlations with both Mania (r = .45) and Well-Being (r = .51); together, these two scales jointly accounted for 46% of the variance in Euphoria. As discussed previously, this pattern is unusual, given that Mania and Well-Being (a) are completely unrelated to one another (r = .02) and (b) tend to have opposite relations with other variables. Despite this complex pattern, however, the scale itself is unidimensional, indicating that this striking duality of content is inherent in the items themselves. In light of these data, Euphoria can be viewed as capturing the elevated, expansive mood that is a hallmark of many manic episodes (American Psychiatric Association, 2000; Gruber, Mauss, & Tamir, 2011); thus, it essentially represents a pathological type of positive affect.

Euphoria showed significant convergent validity in relation to other self-report mania measures, although these associations tended to be more moderate than those observed for Mania (see Table 8). Its strongest associations were with the HPS Total score (r = .45), HPS Excitement subscale (r = .45), IDAS-II Mania (r = .45), and GBI Hypomania (r = .44).

Finally, it is important to note that Euphoria demonstrated strong criterion validity in our data. At the bivariate level, in fact, it had the strongest individual associations with both IMAS Mania (r = .64) and current manic episodes (r = .47). In the multivariate analyses, the scale displayed significant incremental power in predicting IMAS Mania (β = .40) and also showed a nonsignificant trend in relation to current manic episodes (OR = 2.01, p = .054).

In summary, Euphoria showed good convergent validity and substantial criterion validity. Given its highly distinctive nature—and the fact that it contains some unique variance that is not assessed by existing mania scales (see Table 8)—we believe it represents a significant incremental contribution to the assessment of bipolar symptoms.

sec.title: Expanded Scope of the IDAS-II
sec.p: Analyses of the original IDAS scales yielded a single general factor (“Distress”) that essentially represents distress-based symptoms of internalizing (Watson et al., 2007). The inclusion of the seven new scales altered the internal structure of the expanded instrument, which now contains additional dimensions that we labeled Obsessions/Fear and Positive Mood. It is interesting to note that this three-factor model seems to be broadly congruent with the higher order structure of psychopathology (Markon, 2010; Sellbom, Ben-Porath, & Bagby, 2008). For example, Sellbom et al. (2008) reported that the Restructured Clinical Scales of the MMPI-2-RF also define a three-factor structure consisting of Internalizing, Externalizing (which includes manifestations of mania), and Thought Disturbance (a domain that includes OCD symptoms as significant markers; see Chmielewski & Watson, 2008a, 2008b). Thus, the expanded IDAS-II has moved beyond emotion-based manifestations of internalizing and also assesses other important types of symptoms.

sec.title: Importance of longitudinal data
sec.p: Although these results are encouraging, we also must acknowledge several significant limitations of our data. First, we need a broader range of reliability and validity evidence to explicate the construct validity of these scales more fully. For example, our current data are completely cross-sectional in nature so that we do not know how scores on these new scales change as a function of time or in response to treatment. Watson et al. (2007) reported that the original IDAS scales displayed strong short-term retest reliability and also showed some sensitivity to change; it will be important to collect similar data on these new scales.

sec.title: Need for replication
sec.p: Our results are limited to college student, community adult, and psychiatric outpatient samples. It will be important to replicate these findings in other populations, such as adolescents and older adults. Moreover, most of our participants were White and non-Hispanic; it therefore is important to examine the generalizability of these findings in more ethnically diverse samples. Finally, although we were able to show that most of our main criterion validity results replicated across both the IMAS and the SCID, these analyses were limited to a single outpatient sample (Patient Sample 3); it therefore will be important to establish the robustness of these findings in other samples.

sec.title: Changes to the DSM
sec.p: Finally, our criterion validity analyses are limited to DSM-IV symptoms and disorders, which will soon be supplanted by a new nosological scheme (DSM-5) that is scheduled for implementation in 2013 (for information about proposed changes in DSM-5, go to: http://www.dsm5.org/Pages/Default.aspx). Although it will be desirable to collect data on DSM-5 criteria in the future, we do not view this as a significant problem for three reasons. First, it appears that the symptom criteria for those disorders most directly relevant to our scales (e.g., major depression, panic disorder, OCD, PTSD) are not undergoing major changes in DSM-5. For example, the current proposal for DSM-5 PTSD is to replace the existing tripartite scheme with the four-factor King et al. (1998) model; consequently, the one basic change is to separate symptoms of avoidance and numbing into distinct clusters.

Second, the proposed changes in DSM-5 have not yet been finalized. It therefore would be premature to base validity analyses on these tentative new criteria. In fact, we believe that data such as ours have the potential to inform these ongoing deliberations. For instance, consistent with other evidence (e.g., Gootzeit & Markon, 2011; Watson, 2009a), our Phase I data indicated that numbing symptoms have a substantial component of general distress/dysphoria and show poor discriminant validity vis-à-vis depression and other types of internalizing psychopathology. These results raise questions about the overall utility of these numbing symptoms in the diagnosis of PTSD.

Finally—and most important—our scales are designed to assess the basic symptom dimensions underlying DSM disorders, rather than to serve as screening instruments for the diagnoses themselves. As such, they are not closely tethered to the DSM; indeed, it is noteworthy that several scales actually cut across current DSM boundaries. For example, the new Claustrophobia scale assesses content related to both agoraphobia and specific phobia. Similarly, Ill Temper (which taps anger and hostility) and Well-Being (which measures high energy and positive affect) contain content relevant to multiple DSM disorders. In a related vein, the structure defined by the IDAS-II depression scales deviates significantly from the current organization in the DSM. For instance, Lassitude contains items reflecting both fatigue/anergia (Criterion 6 for a major depressive episode) and hypersomnia (part of Criterion 4), whereas Dysphoria subsumes content from five different major depressive episode criteria. Thus, the clinical and research utility of the scales is largely unaffected by periodic changes in the DSM’s specification of these disorders.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In fact, one of our basic goals in developing the IDAS and IDAS-II was to create a diverse instrument that would bypass various problems associated with disorder-based analyses (including the complicating effects of changing diagnostic criteria; see Watson, 2005, 2009a) and provide an alternative dimensional approach for addressing key issues such as (a) the specificity versus nonspecificity of different types of symptom content and (b) the underlying structure of psychopathology. With the addition of these new anxiety and bipolar symptom scales, the expanded IDAS-II now provides broad coverage of the homogeneous symptom dimensions underlying major depression, the bipolar disorders, PTSD, panic disorder, agoraphobia, social phobia, specific phobia, and OCD. Although the instrument still is not completely comprehensive (e.g., its coverage of specific phobia remains limited), this expanded coverage greatly improves its ability to address these important issues.
